author: Forgotten Member
title: Bind to other Prog.Languages
description: Cardano's software is written in Haskell. This represents a great learning curve for many developers who use other more popular languages

assessments.note: The problem the proposal addresses is a real one for developers, but these issues will most likely be addressed by IO internally at an appropriate time. The proposer does not make a convincing proposal commensurate with the funds requested, or outline and details as to how the project will be executed and adopted. For these reasons I do not believe the proposal would have a significant impact.

While in essence the proposal addresses aspects of the challenge, the proposal fails to acknowledge that very similar tools are being implemented under the direct guidance of IOG. I would suggest providing much more detail on how the proposed solutions differ from the ones currently being developed.

Draft proposal. The problem and solution statement makes sense, but IOG and RunTime Verification are already developing solutions to this problem, through KEVM and IELE.

There is no plan, goals and metrics, which makes it impossible to assess the impact of the proposal on this challenge.

This idea is already integrated in the Cardano roadmap and currently in development for the Goguen era. So the proposal is not suggesting something new. The K-framework will create these libraries and using IELE, will enable to run all previous languages on the LLVM devnet.

The user experience benefits of alternative programming language bindings for the Cardano blockchain is self-evident. Developers can use the tools they are familiar with to write Cardano applications. It is not clear whether the proposal refers to alternative bindings for cardano-node or for cardano-addresses or for cardano-cli or what, which is not reassuring.
There are projects underway in IOG for achieving the same aim of the project. The proposer has to start afresh it will be better if gets to work in the projects currently underway.

The proposal suggests creating a bridge between the programming language used by Cardano and other more common languages, which could be beneficial in the sense of attracting new developers who do not work with Haskell. In this way, the idea meets the challenge's objectives well, because in addition to attracting possible new programming professionals, it would encourage them to work in the community, since they would continue with the context (language) they are already comfortable with.

It is not clear if  the proposal will be within the challenge goal, because the information's needed are not clear exposed with minimal descriptions. At the same time the statement of how problem is to be solved (e.g. "…The idea is to have wrapper libraries of the type PyCardano, JsCardano, PhpCardano, …") is not deep specified and remain vague. I suggest to better introduce and explain HOW and WHAT, through use cases related to user's operations
It is hard to say if it will be successful as the proposer has not yet decided what languages to bind. It is not detailed how that choice would be made.

No references to verify the proposer's experience are provided. No detailed plan, timeline, or goals are provided for what is a highly complex and demanding problem.  With such a proposal it is impossible to believe that 140k will be used efficiently, or that a genuine product will be produced.

Insufficient information to properly judge both the team and the deliverables intended to be created by the proposal. In the future I would suggest including at least the information required when doing the self-assessment checklist, i.e. detailed budget, approximate public launch date, a clear definition of success and information about all the team, their background and links to their previous related works.

Draft proposal. There is no plan, how to understand the proposer's ability to implement this proposal when there is no clarity on what will be carried out and there is no plan?

I recommend that the proposal be detailed so that we can give appropriate feedback. Some people commented on the proposal about the fact that IOG is working on the development of IELE and KEVM, but the proposer did not answered.

The proposer had a background in coding. However, the proposal is aiming to create a very similar solution to what is already being developed by IOHK. The set budget is not outlined and there is no reason as to why it would be 140k USD. There are a few comments on the proposal that are justified as to why it is obsolete.

Not enough detail has been provided relative to the $140,000 USD requested. 

As a yardstick, for individuals applying for a job or a grant (elsewhere) paying that much, they have to demonstrate that they are trustworthy, have the expertise to deliver such a project, jump through some hoops, and can produce plans and milestones for the project. 

While Catalyst doesn't mandate such things yet, I can not affirm that this proposal will be implemented successfully without a similar level of vetting.

Developing a bind with the required security assurance supporting formal verification aimed by Cardano is a major challenge. There will be a requirement of the team of the size employed by IOG to achieve success. The proposal does not have enough detail to clarify the issue.

I believe that to execute this idea the necessary skill is unique, the experience in programming, which the author claimed to already have, citing the language he has previously developed. Now, to implement the project with the Catalyst system, it would probably be necessary a more specific planning, for example, how would this new adapted language reach the programmers? I believe that for more bureaucratic issues it would be necessary for someone else to be hired, which is not mentioned in the text, perhaps the author has focused a lot on the technical part and overlooked this detail.

The proposer team states that it has the necessary experience in developing technology (not a lot of languages), but I don't discover team member with experience in blockchain. The given metrics measure what the proposer wants to do, but the success of his actions is not defined. As mentioned above, the description of the solution is not well explained (e.g. how the funds will be spent, how the developers manage their benefits …), so the progress of this proposal is not simple to assess
The proposal should specifically state which languages are going to be bound and a plan for how/when that will be done.

No breakdown of fund allocation, specific timeline or prioritization of languages, or goals for successs are provided.  The quality of the proposal is very low and demonstrates little professionalism.  As the proposal stands it will be impossible to verify how the funds are allocated, and impossible to judge the success of the project.

In theory progress on technical development would be straightforward to audit, however the proposal doesn't include any metrics to measure success by, an estimated project roadmap and timeframe nor a clear description of deliverable.
Draft proposal. There is no data or information that would allow us to audit this proposal. I recommend that a new proposal be developed based on the Catalyst documentation.

There is no detailed information available in this proposal. No roadmap or metrics that would provide an explanation for the cost. Nor does it provide a solution for something that isn't in the works already.
The proposal lack any detail on how to audit the progress and success of the proposal.
There is a requirement for task analysis and the justification for the amount quoted. The progress is measurable however the success in terms of getting verifiable code will be a challenge.

Regarding the applicability of the project, we are basically not provided with any information, only that the author intends to "connect" Haskell as initially 3 other languages. However, as it is a mostly technical action, I cannot imagine how it could be more detailed. Perhaps include a schedule of dates in relation to the progress of the project, for example: in X months, 50% of the schedule would be complete. Another question is regarding the financial amount. It is not said whether all the money would be used to pay for the service of creating the schedule or other things as well, and it is a very high amount.

Roadmap and milestones (incl. time horizon) are not described. The budget provided is very general and therefore I cannot say whether it is appropriate or not. There aren't more details how the budget is going to be spent, also I'm trying to discover attachment to deep dive the solution. Furthermore there aren't information about the connection with blockchain application or benefit for Cardano community...

solution: Developing bindings for other languages that do not force developers to move from the comfort of their usual development environments.
experience: I was the main developer of Abanq n which different bindings were created or collaborated, from C to C ++ and Python, and PyQt
